title: Do I have to file form EJ-100 in California small claims court if I'm still owed post judgment costs?
question: I filed a lien against judgment debtor and they ended paying in full 6 months later but I have since accrued other costs attempting to collect the debt. Do I have to file EJ-100 before I recuperate all post judgment costs as well?
answers:
There is an outer time limit of 2 years for a memorandum of costs after the date the costs were accrued. But if you accepted the full payoff amount in satisfaction, you may have foreclosed those costs.

You should file your memorandum of costs BEFORE accepting a payment satisfying the judgment in full. Once the judgment is satisfied (that is you accept tender), you may have waived your right to those costs entirely.

However, you could file the memo of costs, and if the debtor does not object, submit an approved final judgment for the court to enter for your outstanding costs. I do not suggest this approach though and a savvy debtor will file a motion to strike/tax costs, and possibly get sanctions. Here's why:

There is a case out there from the Fourth District that has come down for remand after the Supreme court (Estate of McQueen) remanded it for reconsideration. It is now final. GRAY1 CPB, LLC v. SCC ACQUISITIONS, INC (2015) 233 Cal. App. 4th 882 which explains you should submit your final memo before accepting tender of payment.

"(§ 685.080, subd. (a); Conservatorship of McQueen, supra, 59 Cal.4th at p.
616; Lucky United Properties Investment, Inc. v. Lee
(2010) 185 Cal.App.4th 125, 141 [110 Cal. Rptr. 3d
159]; Carnes v. Zamani (9th Cir. 2007) 488 F.3d 1057,
1060; cf. § 685.070, subd. (b) [memorandum of costs].)
"'[T]he statutory purpose of requiring that the motion for
enforcement costs be brought "before the judgment is
satisfied in full" (§ 685.080, subd. (a)) is to avoid a
situation where a judgment debtor has paid off the
entirety of what he [justifiably] believes to be his
obligation in the entire case, only to be confronted later
with a motion for yet more fees.' (Lucky United
Properties Investment, Inc. v. Lee, supra, 185
Cal.App.4th at p. 144.)" (Conservatorship of McQueen,
supra, 59 Cal.4th at pp. 615-616.) That is the present
situation"
